contentBody.bodyText:
Keyboard or piano?
These lessons will work fine on either a piano or any sort of keyboard.

All about pitch
When music is written down, notes are shown on a five-line stave (see below). The position of the note on the stave shows the pitch of the note.

How to sit at the keyboard
• Always sit in the middle of the keyboard. Use an adjustable stool, if possible, to find the most comfortable height.

• Sit with your back straight, shoulders in a relaxed position. Imagine there is a string attached to the top of your head, gently pulling upwards.

• Keep your fingers rounded over the keys. Fingers curved, wrists level with your arm. Imagine you are holding a ball under each hand.

• Keep both feet firmly on the ground.

The piano stave
Piano music uses two staves joined together — the top one for the right hand, and the bottom one for the left hand. Together they are called the grand stave.

Notes are grouped into bars (measures) by barlines. At the end of a piece there is a double barline.

The keyboard
The keyboard has groups of black and white notes, which form a repeating pattern. The black notes are grouped in twos and threes. The white notes are named after the first seven letters of the alphabet:
A B C D E F and G.

largePicture.caption: All content taken from It's Never Too Late to Play Piano by Pam Wedgwood © 2006 by Faber Music Ltd.

image.caption: All content taken from It's Never Too Late to Play Piano by Pam Wedgwood © 2006 by Faber Music Ltd.

pages.trailText: Learning to read music is like learning a second language
pages.linkText: Piano and keyboard guide part 1: Lesson 1 - learning to read music

draft.headline: Lesson 1: The basics
draft.standfirst: Learning to read music is like learning a second language. There are no shortcuts - you simply have to slowly familiarise yourself with the grammar and appearance of written music. So, before you begin playing, here's an easy introduction to the piano keyboard and how music is written

largePicture.caption: All content taken from It's Never Too Late to Play Piano by Pam Wedgwood © 2006 by Faber Music Ltd.

image.caption: All content taken from It's Never Too Late to Play Piano by Pam Wedgwood © 2006 by Faber Music Ltd.

live.standfirst: Learning to read music is like learning a second language. There are no shortcuts - you simply have to slowly familiarise yourself with the grammar and appearance of written music. So, before you begin playing, here's an easy introduction to the piano keyboard and how music is written
